text: this is mato grosso in central brazil in
portuguese mato grosso means thick
forests but in the past decade the
forest here have been rapidly cleared
for ranching and agriculture there is
fertile soil underneath the trees in
Mato Grosso and today this area is
Brazil's leading producer of soy corn
and cattle I'm Libby Rosenthal for the
New York Times recently I flew over mato
grosso with John Carter a rancher
originally from Texas fifteen years ago
he moved with his Brazilian wife here
deep into the forest with no phones or
electricity and from that vantage point
he's watched the Amazon forest disappear
around him more than 700 square miles
were cleared in 2007 alone when I first
moved here I was a lot more humid of
course they're a lot more specifically
in our ranch a lot more birdlife parrots
flying over the mornings in the evenings
the forest was not flammable at that
time deforestation fires usually burned
out when they hit the forest because
it's too humid and today those same
forest or that are still standing there
too they've become flammable and they've
dried out and now they're combustible
and Bernie now the lure of profits from
food production drives the deforestation
in this area much of the soy grown in
mato grosso is for export bought by
multinational companies to feed cattle
as far away as Europe but protecting
virgin forest and letting degraded
forests regrow also has great value in
the fight against climate change twenty
percent of global emissions can be
traced to deforestation by some accounts
those emissions come from the fires and
the machinery used to clear the land
also when forests are felled we lose the
carbon dioxide absorbing capacity of
their trees the forest that stant have
withstood the pressures economic
pressures most all of its degraded in
some way it's been logged or burned and
you can
see that by as a pilot flying in the
burning season sub story fires smoke
billowing out of the out of the canopy
and so I it's a it's a striking point of
view when you're above looking down
cleared land is worth almost thirteen
hundred dollars an acre five times as
much as virgin forest these days mr.
Carter is trying to broker deals between
farmers and ranchers on the one side and
banks and environmental groups on the
other in order to help preserve the
Amazons forests farmers who join his
group alian√ßa de terre agreed to have
their land survey for environmental good
practice and especially for forest
preservation you have to work with the
fact that landowners for the most part
our land stewards they want to take care
of the land if they don't if they
degrade it in a long term they don't
have the sustainability they need to
stay in business mr. Carter wants to
create a label for food produced on
farms that respect their forests he's
already met with a number of companies
including McDonald's in the hopes that
they will agree to only buy ingredients
from approved farms or ranches we're
going to say we're going to show the
problem and quantify it scientifically
and then look for some way to benefit us
economically so that we can revert and
pull the pin back in the other direction
so we're working with landowners today
we have over 5 million acres in our
system Brazil has already set up what it
calls the Amazon fund with a hundred
million dollars from Norway that country
is pledged another billion dollars as
deforestation is curbed the United
Nations plan to curtail deforestation is
called red or reducing emissions from
deforestation and degradation it will
also pay landowners to conserve forests
and farmers and ranchers here in mato
grosso seem to be coming around they're
sensing that there may be for the first
time money in keeping their far as
standing rather than cutting them down
